snippet: A company with deep ties to Gov. Chris Christie dominates New Jersey’s system of large halfway houses. There has been little state oversight, despite widespread problems.
abstract: New Jersey, grappling with crowded prisons, has become a leader in a national movement to save money by diverting inmates to a new kind of privately run halfway house; halfway houses have mutated into a shadow corrections network, where drugs, gang activity and violence often go unchecked; system is largely administered by Community Education Centers, company that has deep connections to politicians of both parties, including Gov Chris Christie (Series: Unlocked).

byline.contributor: Jo Craven McGinty, Sheelagh McNeill and Jack Styczynski contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: A company with deep ties to Gov. Chris Christie dominates New Jersey’s system of large halfway houses. There has been little state oversight, despite widespread problems.

headline.seo: In New Jersey Halfway Houses, Escapees Stream Out as a Penal Business Thrives
